questions.title: Estimation and Inference
questions.question: Which one of the following statements is true about non-probability sampling?

choices.A: There is significant risk that the sample is not representative of the population.
choices.B: Every member of the population has an equal chance of being selected for the sample.
choices.C: Using judgment guarantees that population subdivisions of interest are represented in the sample.

questions.explanation: Solution A is correct. Because non-probability sampling is dependent on factors other than probability considerations, such as a samplerâ€™s judgment or the convenience to access data, there is a significant risk that non-probability sampling might generate a non-representative sample.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

A is correct. Because non-probability sampling is dependent on factors other than probability considerations, such as a samplerâ€™s judgment or the convenience to access data, there is a significant risk that non-probability sampling might generate a non-representative sample.

questions.title: Estimation and Inference
questions.question:
If the distribution of the population from which samples of size n are drawn is positively skewed and given that the sample size, n, is large, the sampling distribution of the sample means is most likely to have a:

  1. mean smaller than the mean of the entire population.
  2. variance equal to that of the entire population.
  3. distribution that is approximately normal.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Given a population that has a finite variance and a large sample size, the central limit theorem establishes that the sampling distribution of samples means will have a mean equal to the population mean. Incorrect. Given a population that has a finite variance and a large sample size, the central limit theorem establishes that the sampling distribution of sample means will have a variance equal to the population variance divided by the sample size. Correct . Given a population that has a finite variance and a large sample size, the central limit theorem establishes that the sampling distribution of sample means will be approximately normal, will have a mean equal to the population mean, and will have a variance equal to the population variance divided by the sample size. Estimation and Inference explain the central limit theorem and its importance for the distribution and standard error of the sample mean
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Given a population that has a finite variance and a large sample size, the central limit theorem establishes that the sampling distribution of samples means will have a mean equal to the population mean.

  2. Incorrect. Given a population that has a finite variance and a large sample size, the central limit theorem establishes that the sampling distribution of sample means will have a variance equal to the population variance divided by the sample size.

  3. Correct. Given a population that has a finite variance and a large sample size, the central limit theorem establishes that the sampling distribution of sample means will be approximately normal, will have a mean equal to the population mean, and will have a variance equal to the population variance divided by the sample size.

Estimation and Inference

questions.title: Estimation and Inference
questions.question: The best approach for creating a stratified random sample of a population involves:

choices.A: drawing an equal number of simple random samples from each subpopulation.
choices.B: selecting every k th member of the population until the desired sample size is reached.
choices.C: drawing simple random samples from each subpopulation in sizes proportional to the relative size of each subpopulation.

questions.explanation: Solution C is correct. Stratified random sampling involves dividing a population into subpopulations based on one or more classification criteria. Then, simple random samples are drawn from each subpopulation in sizes proportional to the relative size of each subpopulation. These samples are then pooled to form a stratified random sample.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

C is correct. Stratified random sampling involves dividing a population into subpopulations based on one or more classification criteria. Then, simple random samples are drawn from each subpopulation in sizes proportional to the relative size of each subpopulation. These samples are then pooled to form a stratified random sample.

questions.title: Estimation and Inference
questions.question: A population has a non-normal distribution with mean Âµ and variance Ïƒ2. The sampling distribution of the sample mean computed from samples of large size from that population will have:

choices.A: the same distribution as the population distribution.
choices.B: its mean approximately equal to the population mean.
choices.C: its variance approximately equal to the population variance.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. Given a population described by any probability distribution (normal or non-normal) with finite variance, the central limit theorem states that the sampling distribution of the sample mean will be approximately normal, with the mean approximately equal to the population mean, when the sample size is large.

Solution

B is correct. Given a population described by any probability distribution (normal or non-normal) with finite variance, the central limit theorem states that the sampling distribution of the sample mean will be approximately normal, with the mean approximately equal to the population mean, when the sample size is large.

questions.title: Estimation and Inference
questions.question:
A descriptive measure of a population characteristic is best described as a:

  1. parameter.
  2. sample statistic.
  3. frequency distribution.
questions.explanation: Solution Correct because any descriptive measure of a population characteristic is called a parameter. Incorrect because sample statistic is a quantity computed from or used to describe a sample. Incorrect because a frequency distribution is a tabular display of data summarized into a relatively small number of intervals. Estimation and Inference compare and contrast simple random, stratified random, cluster, convenience, and judgmental sampling and their implications for sampling error in an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Correct because any descriptive measure of a population characteristic is called a parameter.

  2. Incorrect because sample statistic is a quantity computed from or used to describe a sample.

  3. Incorrect because a frequency distribution is a tabular display of data summarized into a relatively small number of intervals.

Estimation and Inference

  • compare and contrast simple random, stratified random, cluster, convenience, and judgmental sampling and their implications for sampling error in an investment problem

questions.title: Estimation and Inference
questions.question:
The distribution of all the distinct possible values for a statistic when calculated from samples of the same size randomly drawn from the same population is most accurately referred to as:

  1. a discrete uniform distribution.
  2. a multivariate normal distribution.
  3. the sampling distribution of a statistic.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. Discrete uniform distribution refers to the distribution of equally likely outcomes. Incorrect. Multivariate normal distribution specifies the probabilities for a group of related random variables. Correct . The sampling distribution of a statistic (like a sample mean) is defined as the probability distribution of a given sample statistic when samples of the same size are randomly drawn from the same population. Estimation and Inference compare and contrast simple random, stratified random, cluster, convenience, and judgmental sampling and their implications for sampling error in an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. Discrete uniform distribution refers to the distribution of equally likely outcomes.

  2. Incorrect. Multivariate normal distribution specifies the probabilities for a group of related random variables.

  3. Correct. The sampling distribution of a statistic (like a sample mean) is defined as the probability distribution of a given sample statistic when samples of the same size are randomly drawn from the same population.

Estimation and Inference

  • compare and contrast simple random, stratified random, cluster, convenience, and judgmental sampling and their implications for sampling error in an investment problem

questions.title: Estimation and Inference
questions.question: Compared with bootstrap resampling, jackknife resampling:

choices.B: usually requires that the number of repetitions is equal to the sample size.
choices.C: produces dissimilar results for every run because resamples are randomly drawn.

questions.explanation: Solution B is correct. For a sample of size n , jackknife resampling usually requires n repetitions. In contrast, with bootstrap resampling, we are left to determine how many repetitions are appropriate.
questions.solution_html:
Solution

B is correct. For a sample of size n, jackknife resampling usually requires n repetitions. In contrast, with bootstrap resampling, we are left to determine how many repetitions are appropriate.

questions.title: Estimation and Inference
questions.question:
A subset of a population is best described as a:

  1. statistic.
  2. sample.
  3. conditional distribution.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because a statistic is a quantity computed from or used to describe a sample of data. Correct because we often need to infer information on a population (all members of a specified group) through samples (part of the population). Hence a sample is a subset of the population. Incorrect because a conditional distribution is a misnomer, but it sounds like the distribution of some value conditional upon some event. Estimation and Inference compare and contrast simple random, stratified random, cluster, convenience, and judgmental sampling and their implications for sampling error in an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because a statistic is a quantity computed from or used to describe a sample of data.

  2. Correct because we often need to infer information on a population (all members of a specified group) through samples (part of the population). Hence a sample is a subset of the population.

  3. Incorrect because a conditional distribution is a misnomer, but it sounds like the distribution of some value conditional upon some event.

Estimation and Inference

  • compare and contrast simple random, stratified random, cluster, convenience, and judgmental sampling and their implications for sampling error in an investment problem

  2. difference between the observed value of a statistic and the quantity it is intended to estimate.
  3. sum of squared deviations from the mean divided by the sample size minus one.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect. The sample standard deviation divided by the square root of the sample size is the standard error of the sample mean. Correct . The sampling error is the difference between the observed value of a statistic and the quantity it is intended to estimate. Incorrect. The sum of squared deviations from the mean divided by the sample size minus one is the sample variance. questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect. The sample standard deviation divided by the square root of the sample size is the standard error of the sample mean.

  2. Correct. The sampling error is the difference between the observed value of a statistic and the quantity it is intended to estimate.

  3. Incorrect. The sum of squared deviations from the mean divided by the sample size minus one is the sample variance.

questions.title: Estimation and Inference
questions.question:
Grouping all publicly traded US firms by sector and then randomly selecting subsamples of firms from each sector according to the sector's proportion in the total population is an example of:

  1. cluster sampling.
  2. simple random sampling.
  3. stratified random sampling.
questions.explanation: Solution Incorrect because, in cluster sampling, the population is divided into clusters, each of which is essentially a mini-representation of the entire populations. Then certain clusters are chosen as a whole using simple random sampling. The sampling method used by the analyst is not cluster sampling because, first, each sector is not a mini-representation of all public firms; second, certain sectors are not chosen as a whole. Incorrect because, in simple random sampling, a public firm would be randomly selected without the firms being grouped into sectors first. A simple random sample is a subset of a larger population created in such a way that each element of the population has an equal probability of being selected to the subset. Correct because, in stratified random sampling, the population is divided into subpopulations (strata) based on one or more classification criteria. Simple random samples are then drawn from each stratum in sizes proportional to the relative size of each stratum in the population. Estimation and Inference compare and contrast simple random, stratified random, cluster, convenience, and judgmental sampling and their implications for sampling error in an investment problem
questions.solution_html:
Solution

  1. Incorrect because, in cluster sampling, the population is divided into clusters, each of which is essentially a mini-representation of the entire populations. Then certain clusters are chosen as a whole using simple random sampling. The sampling method used by the analyst is not cluster sampling because, first, each sector is not a mini-representation of all public firms; second, certain sectors are not chosen as a whole.

  2. Incorrect because, in simple random sampling, a public firm would be randomly selected without the firms being grouped into sectors first. A simple random sample is a subset of a larger population created in such a way that each element of the population has an equal probability of being selected to the subset.

  3. Correct because, in stratified random sampling, the population is divided into subpopulations (strata) based on one or more classification criteria. Simple random samples are then drawn from each stratum in sizes proportional to the relative size of each stratum in the population.

Estimation and Inference

  • compare and contrast simple random, stratified random, cluster, convenience, and judgmental sampling and their implications for sampling error in an investment problem
